revision.text:
{{Infobox military unit | unit_name= ''Comando de la Fuerza de Submarinos''
Argentine Submarine Force | image = [[File:SubmarinosTR.jpg|250px]] | caption = TR1700s at Mar del Plata naval base (2007) | dates= 1927 – present | country= {{ARG}} | allegiance= | branch= {{navy|Argentina}} | type= [[submarines]] | role= | size= 3 | command_structure= [[Argentine Navy|Navy]]
[[Ministry of Defense (Argentina)|Ministry of Defense]] | garrison= | garrison_label= Command HQ | equipment= | nickname= | patron= | motto= | colors= | colors_label= | march= | mascot= | battles= [[Revolucion Libertadora]]
[[Falklands War]] | anniversaries= September 3 | decorations= | battle_honours= | commander1= [[President of Argentina|President of the Republic]] | commander1_label= Commander-in-Chief | commander2= Admiral | commander2_label= Chief of Staff of the Navy | commander3= [[Ship-of-the-Line Captain|Capitán de Navío]] | commander3_label= Chief of COFS | notable_commanders= }} The '''Argentine Submarine Force''' ([[Spanish language|Spanish]]: '''Comando de la Fuerza de Submarinos''', '''COFS''') is the [[submarine|submarine service]] branch of the [[Argentine Navy]]. Argentine submarines have traditionally been named after the [[Provinces of Argentina|provinces of the Republic]] whose name begins with the letter 'S'; they are home based at [[Mar del Plata]] naval base. COFS members have the same rank insignia and titles as the rest of the Navy. As of 2010, the elite group ''[[Tactical Divers Group|Agrupación de Buzos Tácticos]]'' is under the direct command of the submarine force; two [[TR-1700 class submarine|TR-1700]] and one [[Type 209 submarine|Type 209]] submarines are in service. Two small surface vessels, ARA ''Punta Mogotes'' (P-65) and ARA ''Luisito'' (Q-51), are also part of the COFS and used in the training role. Like the rest of the Argentine armed services the force is struggling to maintain its readiness in the absence of funds for maintenance and training. All three boats have maintenance difficulties and between them spent just 19 hours submerged in 2012.{{cite web | url=http://en.mercopress.com/2012/11/22/argentine-navy-short-on-spares-and-resources-for-training-and-maintenance | title= Argentine navy short on spares and resources for training and maintenance |date= 22 November 2012 | publisher=MercoPress}} It is currently composed of three submarines: [[ARA Salta (S-31)]], [[ARA Santa Cruz (S-41)]] and [[ARA San Juan (S-42)]]. == History == In 1917 the Navy sent students to the [[United States]] to begin training courses at the [[Naval Submarine Base New London]]. Lieutenants Francis Lajous, Osvaldo Repeto, Eduardo Ceballos and Vicente Ferrer served in the [[US Navy]] during the [[First World War]]. === First generation === [[File:Clase Santa Fe.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Argentine first submarines Santa Fe class and submarine tender ''General Belgrano'' in Mar del Plata naval base]] In 1927 the Argentine Navy signed a contract with the Italian [[shipyard]] [[Cantieri navali Tosi di Taranto|Franco Tosi]] of [[Taranto]] in order to build the service's first three ships. The units arrived in [[Buenos Aires]] on April 7, 1933 and transferred to Mar del Plata on September 3, which became the Anniversary Day for the newly created Submarine Force. The ''Tarantinos'', as they were known, served between 1933 and 1960 when the last one, ''Santa Fe'' (S-1), was retired after taking over a thousand dives. In 1938, the crew of the ''Santa Fe'' had been awarded a civilian medal after assisting a local fishing boat that was in distress off Cabo Corrientes.Paz, R., Tamburini, F. and Iñurrieta, V. (2009). ''Los Tarantinos: Argentina 1933- 1960. Historia de Submarinos''. ElSnorkel, p. 151. ISBN 987-25327-0-2 {{es icon}} ''Santiago del Estero'' (S-2) established (at the time) an immersion record for a submarine in the [[South Atlantic]] (114 metres).Paz, Tamburini and Iñurrieta, p. 150 ''Santiago del Estero'' took part in the blockade of the [[Rio de la Plata]] during the 1955 [[Revolución Libertadora]], where she fought off a strike package of [[Gloster Meteor]] fighters loyal to president [[Juan Domingo Peron]].Paz, Tamburini and Iñurrieta, pp. 150-151 * [[ARA Santa Fe (S-1)|ARA ''Santa Fe'' (S-1)]] * [[ARA Santiago del Estero (S-2)|ARA ''Santiago del Estero'' (S-2)]] * [[ARA Salta (S-3)|ARA ''Salta'' (S-3)]] === Second generation === [[File:ARA-Stgo.jpg|thumb|200px|ARA ''Santiago del Estero'' (S-12) after being upgraded in Mar del Plata]] In April 1960 the US Navy agreed to transfer two {{sclass|Balao|submarine}} units on loan under the [[Military Assistance Program]]. They departed from [[San Francisco]], California on September 23 of the same year and arrived in Mar del Plata on November 30. These ships participated in numerous exercises during their career including UNITAS, CAIMAN, SAYONARA and CAIO DULIO. The conning towers of both submarines were locally upgraded to improve [[hydrodynamics]].[http://www.histarmar.com.ar/Armada%20Argentina/Submarinos%20Argentinos/Balao.htm ''Historia y Arqueologia Marítima: Submarinos Clase "Balao"]'' {{es icon}} Some years ago, Argentinian officials disclosed that a group of [[Tactical Divers Group|tactical divers]] had carried out an incursion on the [[Falkland Islands]] on board the ''[[Santiago del Estero]]'' (S-12) in October 1966.[http://edant.clarin.com/diario/96/03/31/malvinas.html ''Malvinas: Los Secretos de la Guerra''] [[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|Clarín]], 31 March 1996 {{es icon}} The submarines went back to the United States for mid-life repairs and were finally retired in 1971. * [[ARA Santa Fe (S-11)|ARA ''Santa Fe'' (S-11)]], ex {{USS|Macabi|SS-375}} * [[ARA Santiago del Estero (S-12)|ARA ''Santiago del Estero'' (S-12)]], ex {{USS|Lamprey|SS-372}} === Third generation === [[File:ARASantiagodelEsteroS22.jpg|thumb|right|200px|ARA ''Santiago del Estero'' (S-22)]] In 1971 the US Navy transferred further units in order to replace the previous generation. Two [[Greater Underwater Propulsion Power Program|GUPPY-type]] submarines were an interim measure until new submarines being built in Europe became available. ''Santiago del Estero'' was retired by September 1981 but [[ARA Santa Fe (S-21)|''Santa Fe'']] (S-21) would take part in the 1982 [[Falklands War]]. She landed a team of ''Buzos Tácticos'' ([[Tactical Divers Group|tactical divers]]) on the [[1982 invasion of the Falkland Islands|initial amphibious assault]] and weeks later, after a successful resupply mission, was spotted on the surface. She was attacked and disabled off [[Grytviken]], [[South Georgia]]; the submarine was scuttled in deep waters by the British some years after the war ended. * [[ARA Santa Fe (S-21)|ARA ''Santa Fe'' (S-21)]], ex {{USS|Catfish|SS-339}} * [[ARA Santiago del Estero (S-22)|ARA ''Santiago del Estero'' (S-22)]], ex {{USS|Chivo|SS-341}} === Fourth generation === [[File:S31ARASalta.jpg|thumb|right|200px|ARA ''Salta'' (S-31)]] In 1969 a contract was signed in [[West Germany]] for two [[Type 209 submarine]]s. The ships were of the 56 metres/1100 ton sub-type; they were built in parts by [[Howaldtswerke]] at Kiel and delivered to [[Tandanor]] shipyard in Buenos Aires where final assembly was completed in 1973. The vessels were commissioned in 1974, but only [[ARA San Luis (S-32)|''San Luis'']] (S-32) was in service during the 1982 [[Falklands War]]. She reported two encounters with [[Royal Navy]] ships but without scoring hits due to problems with her torpedo's firing system. The threat posed by the ''San Luis'', however, forced the Royal Navy to give up recovery efforts of two [[Westland Sea King|Sea King]] helicopters which had ditched at sea on 12 May and 18 May 1982 respectively. Both aircraft were eventually destroyed by naval gunfire.[http://www.ukserials.com/losses-1982.htm UK Military Aircraft Losses - 1982] [[Wolverhampton]] Aviation GroupHoward, L. Burrow, M and Myall, E. (2011). ''Fleet Air Arm Helicopters since 1943''. Staplefield, p. 239. ISBN 978-0-85130-304-8 She also tied up a considerable number of British naval assets deployed to counter her presence.[http://handle.dtic.mil/100.2/ADA279554 Submarine Operations during the Falklands War - Lt Cdr Steven R. Harper USN] There was an attempt to deploy the ''Salta'' to the Falklands area at the end of May, but excessive noise and problems with the torpedo firing system similar to those found on ''San Luis'' prevented her operational use.[http://www.laperlaaustral.com.ar/contenidos/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=56:elsecretodelarasalta&catid=40:fuerzaanvalargentina&Itemid=58 El Secreto del ARA Salta] by Jorge Rafael Bóveda {{es icon}} ''San Luis'' was struck from the Navy in 1997 after an incomplete overhaul, whilst [[ARA Salta (S-31)|''Salta'']] (S-31) was still in service as of 2013. * [[ARA Salta (S-31)|ARA ''Salta'' (S-31)]] * [[ARA San Luis (S-32)|ARA ''San Luis'' (S-32)]] === Fifth generation === [[File:S42ARASanJuan.jpg|thumb|right|200px|ARA ''San Juan'' (S-42)]] As part of a major fleet renovation plan which included the [[MEKO]] frigates classes, a contract was signed in 1977 with West Germany's [[Nordseewerke]] for six [[TR-1700 class submarine|TR-1700 class]] submarines, the last four of them to be built in Argentina. The Argentine Navy sponsored the development of the [[CAREM]] nuclear reactor to be installed on these submarines,[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=1271651 '' El Carem fue diseñado a partir de la idea de técnicos navales para incluir un reactor de esas características en los submarinos comprados a Alemania en la década del 70''] {{es icon}} but for political reasons the whole program was cancelled and only the two German units were delivered. These ships are the largest submarines built in Germany since World War II and are among the fastest diesel-electric submarines in the world.{{cite book | last = Miller | first = David | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = The Illustrated Directory of Submarines | publisher = Zenith Press | year = 2002 | location = | pages = 480 | url = | doi = | isbn = 0-7603-1345-8 }} * [[ARA Santa Cruz (S-41)]] * [[ARA San Juan (S-42)]] == References == * History section of official website * [http://www.soldadosdigital.com/2010/militaria/militaria18-11-10.html Submarinos Argentinos] at soldadosdigital.com {{reflist|2}} == External links == {{commons|:Category:Submarines of Argentina|Submarines of Argentina}} * {{es icon}} [http://www.ara.mil.ar/pag.asp?idItem=211 History of Submarine force at Official site] * [http://www.ara.mil.ar/pag.asp?idItem=119 Official Museum] * {{es icon}} [http://www.deyseg.com.ar/notas/historia/aanota24-subs.htm Fuerza de Submarinos de la Armada Argentina] at deyseg.com.ar * {{es icon}} [http://www.elsnorkel.com/web/fuerzas-latinas/argentina.html Argentine submarines] at elsnorkel.com {{Argentine Military}} [[Category:Argentine Navy]] [[Category:Submarines of the Argentine Navy|*]] [[Category:Military units and formations of Argentina in the Falklands War]] [[Category:Mar del Plata]] [[Category:Military units and formations established in 1927]] [[Category:Lists of submarines]]
